required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Rocuronium Induced Neuromuscular Blockade in Late Second Trimester Pregnant and Non-pregnant Women
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Rocuronium Induced Neuromuscular Blockade in Late Second Trimester Pregnant and Non-pregnant Women

lead_sponsor.agency: Hallym University Kangnam Sacred Heart Hospital

clinical_study.source: Hallym University Kangnam Sacred Heart Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: The present study is to compare the onset and duration of rocuronium in late second trimester women and non-pregnant women undergoing general anesthesia.

detailed_description.textblock:
Pregnancy induces physiological changes. Plasma volume, cardiac output, hepatic blood flow and protein binding are changed from the first trimester of pregnancy. These physiological changes give effect to the onset and duration of neuromuscular blocking drugs.
Rocuronium is a commonly used neuromuscular blocking drug categorized as FDA category B. Rocuronium is widely used for pregnant women. Previous studies have evaluated the onset and duration of rocuronium in postpartum women. Lately, the investigators have evaluated the onset and duration of rocuronium in early second trimester pregnant women and the duration was significantly longer in early second trimester women compared to non-pregnant women.
Since there is little research on the onset and duration of rocuronium in the late second trimester pregnant women, the investigators planned the present research.

primary_outcome.time_frame: time measured to 25% recovery with T1 using Train of Four watch, assessed upto 1 hour

secondary_outcome.time_frame: time measured to 0% depression of T1 using Train of Four watch, assessed upto 5 minutes

study_pop.textblock: case: late second trimester pregnant women undergoing general anesthesia control: non-pregnant women undergoing general anesthesia

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- women undergoing general anesthesia
Exclusion Criteria:
- liver disease
- renal disease
- diabetes mellitus
- asthma
- allergic to specific drugs
- BMI>30 or <18

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Hallym University Kangnam Sacred Heart Hospital
